profileText: A Delegate from New York; born in Albany, N.Y., July 14, 1751; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1771 and commenced practice in Albany, N.Y.; colonel of Light Cavalry in the Revolutionary War; member of the Provincial Congress in 1775 and 1776; president of New York from April 18 to May 14, 1777; clerk of Albany County in 1777 and 1778; member of the State assembly in 1778, 1779, and 1788; member of the commercial convention in Annapolis, Md., in 1786; Member of the Continental Congress in 1788; served in the State senate 1791-1793; judge of Albany County 1794-1797; member of the council of appointment in 1797; judge of the probate court from 1799 until his death in Albany, N.Y., August 26, 1810; interment in Albany Rural Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: In the New York Miscellaneous Correspondence, 1760-1942, 56 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers include letters received by Leonard Gansevoort.

researchRecord.name: 1774, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Leonard Gansevoort to Peter Van Schaack written on October 24, 1774. Leonard Gansevoort discusses legal matters in the letter.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1778-1799, 3 boxes.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Leonard Gansevoort consist of letters, legal documents, and account books relating to his interests in business, government, and politics. Among the letters, there are some that concern the appointment of delegates to represent New York State at the Continental Congress held in 1778, and the process of choosing State Assembly candidates in 1799. Other papers include two bills of sale for slaves purchased by Leonard Gansevoort, as well as two bound folio account journals providing a chronological record of receipts and disbursements from January 1788 to March 1794. An unpublished finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: 1778, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Leonard Gansevoort to John Ten Broeck written on October 15, 1778. Leonard Gansevoort writes regarding developments in the state legislature and bewails the slow pace of activity, but indicates that progress toward the selection of New York's delegates to the Continental Congress is progressing.

researchRecord.name: 1799, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Leonard Gansevoort to Stephen Van Rensselaer written on April 7, 1799. Leonard Gansevoort writes concerning the recent selection of a candidate for the New York State Assembly from the Town of Bethlehem, Albany County, New York. Leonard Gansevoort complains that the "mode which they have adopted of choosing the candidates by ballot is novel and cannot be submitted to as it is an abandonment of the principle which ought to govern."

researchRecord.name: In the John Lansing Papers, 1776-1823, 22 items.
researchRecord.description: Subjects covered include Leonard Gansevoort. An unpublished finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Jacob Morris Papers, 1792, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Jacob Morris to Leonard Gansevoort and others regarding Jacob Morris's nomination for election as a state senator. Jacob Morris solicits advice as to whether he should accept the nomination and adds that if a majority of the voters in the city and county of Albany desire him to accept the nomination, then he will accept it. If they do not, he will place a notice in the papers withdrawing his name.

researchRecord.name: In the Anthony Ten Eyck Papers, 1797, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Anthony Ten Eyck and others, including Leonard Gansevoort, to Stephen Van Rensselaer. The letter urges these men to disregard a petition to enlarge the boundaries of Rennsselaerwyck and Troy by dividing Greenbush and suggests that enlargement of the towns is a political move to gain voting support. The letter also includes a mention of a petition to the contrary to be circulated by them and sent to the state legislature.

researchRecord.name: In the Peter Gansevoort Papers, 1783-1832, approximately 800 items.
